Component-separated, CIB-cleaned thermal Sunyaevâ€“Zelâ€™dovich maps from Planck PR4 data with a flexible public needlet ILC pipeline

Fiona McCarthy fmccarthy@flatironinstitute.org Center for Computational Astrophysics, Flatiron Institute, New York, NY, USA 10010 â€ƒâ€ƒ J.Â Colin Hill jch2200@columbia.edu Department of Physics, Columbia University, 538 West 120th Street, New York, NY, USA 10027 Center for Computational Astrophysics, Flatiron Institute, New York, NY, USA 10010
(February 15, 2024)
Abstract

We use the full-mission Planck PR4 data to construct maps of the thermal Sunyaevâ€“Zelâ€™dovich effect (Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y parameter) in our Universe. To do so, we implement a custom needlet internal linear combination (NILC) pipeline in a Python package, pyilc, which we make publicly available. We publicly release our Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y maps, which we construct using various constrained ILC (â€œdeprojectionâ€) options in order to minimize contamination from the cosmic infrared background (CIB) in the reconstructed signal. In particular, we use a moment-based deprojection which minimizes sensitivity to the assumed frequency dependence of the CIB. Our code pyilc performs needlet or harmonic ILC on mm-wave sky maps in a flexible manner, with options to deproject various components on all or some scales. We validate our maps and compare them to the official Planck 2015 yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map, finding that we obtain consistent results on large scales and 10-20% lower noise on small scales. We expect that these maps will be useful for many auto- and cross-correlation analyses; in a companion paper, we use them to measure the tSZ â€“ CMB lensing cross-correlation. We anticipate that pyilc will be useful both for data analysis and for pipeline validation on simulations to understand the propagation of foreground components through a full NILC pipeline.

I Introduction

Observations of the millimeter-wave sky contain contributions from many sources, both Galactic and extragalactic. The signals of cosmological interest include, of course, the primary cosmic microwave background (CMB)Â Dicke etÂ al. (1965); Penzias and Wilson (1965) â€” the photons that have been free-streaming since recombination without scattering â€” along with the Sunyaevâ€“Zelâ€™dovich (SZ) effectÂ Zeldovich and Sunyaev (1969); Sunyaev and Zeldovich (1970), which is sourced by the scattering of the CMB photons from free electrons in the late Universe, and the cosmic infrared background (CIB)Â Puget etÂ al. (1996); Dwek etÂ al. (1998); Fixsen etÂ al. (1998), which is the thermal radiation of dust grains in star-forming galaxies that are heated by starlight. As we can extract very different information from the different signals, it is useful to be able to separate them. It is common to do so by observing the sky at multiple frequencies and separating the signals based on their differing frequency behavior. In particular, the CMB intensity behaves as a perfect blackbody, with a temperature of 2.726 KK\mathrm{K}roman_KÂ Fixsen etÂ al. (1996); Mather etÂ al. (1999); Fixsen (2009). The thermal SZ (tSZ) effect â€” the scattering of CMB photons by high-temperature electrons â€” induces a well-understood distortion in this spectrum, allowing the tSZ anisotropies to be separated cleanly from the primary CMB.

Many component separation algorithms exist for performing such separation (see, e.g.,Â Bennett etÂ al. (2003); MartÃ­nez-GonzÃ¡lez etÂ al. (2003); Eriksen etÂ al. (2008); Seljebotn etÂ al. (2017); Delabrouille etÂ al. (2009); Remazeilles etÂ al. (2011a); Cardoso etÂ al. (2008); Hurier etÂ al. (2013)). In particular, we focus on the internal linear combination (ILC), a method that creates linear combinations of maps using the well-understood frequency behavior of a signal of interest, such as the blackbody CMB or the tSZ effect, and which has been applied to CMB data for decadesÂ Bennett etÂ al. (2003). Importantly, this is a â€œblindâ€ component separation technique, in that the frequency behavior of the contaminants does not need to be known a priori. This is necessary, as the CIB â€” while observed to generally behave as a modified blackbody, with its emission dominant (with respect to the CMB) at higher frequencies (â‰³greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsimâ‰³353 GHz, although on small scales the CIB anisotropies are dominant at lower frequencies than this) â€” does not have a well-understood spectral energy distribution (SED), or frequency dependence, that can be derived from first principles. However, when the SED of a contaminant is known, this information can be used in the ILC to create a map that is completely insensitive to this contaminantÂ Chen and Wright (2009); Remazeilles etÂ al. (2011b) (or partially less sensitive than the unconstrained estimateÂ Abylkairov etÂ al. (2021)), although at the expense of higher variance in the overall reconstruction. This â€œdeprojectionâ€ of foreground components, known as a â€œconstrainedâ€ ILC, is useful for example in the case of cross-correlations, when one is cross-correlating a component of interest with another signal that is highly correlated with a contaminant.

In this work, we use a needlet ILC (NILC) algorithm to construct maps of the tSZ effect using Planck PR4 (NPIPE) dataÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2020a); we note that several yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps have previously been made with Planck dataÂ Hill and Spergel (2014); Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a); Tanimura etÂ al. (2022); Chandran etÂ al. (2023). We also release maps in which we have deprojected the CIB in various ways, both with a standard CIB deprojection using an estimate of the CIB SED, and in a more theory-independent method where we deproject the first moments of the CIB SED, following the methods ofÂ Chluba etÂ al. (2017); in a companion paperÂ McCarthy and Hill (2024) we use these maps to measure the cross-correlation of the tSZ signal with CMB lensing convergence (Îºğœ…\kappaitalic_Îº) in Planck PR4 data using a publicly-available Planck Îºğœ…\kappaitalic_Îº reconstructionÂ Carron etÂ al. (2022).

We validate our Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y maps and compare them to that from the 2015 Planck releaseÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a). While this work was in the final stages of preparation, a similar analysis performing NILC on Planck PR4 data appearedÂ Chandran etÂ al. (2023). We defer a comparison to this map to future work.

A central purpose of this paper is also to release a user-friendly Python package pyilc, a flexible code which can perform needlet and harmonic ILC on curved-sky maps for various specifications of needlet domains. This is (to our knowledge) the first publicly available needlet ILC code.

This paper is structured as follows. In SectionÂ II we describe the datasets we use to construct the ILC maps. SectionÂ III presents a pedagogical overview of the NILC algorithm and the â€œILC biasâ€. In SectionÂ IV we describe our pipeline to construct a yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map from the data using the NILC approach, including our exact analysis settings. SectionÂ V discusses the various CIB deprojection options that we implement. In SectionÂ VI we validate our yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps, compute their power spectra, compare them to that of the official Planck release, and quantify the amount of CIB contamination in the various deprojections. We discuss our results and conclude in SectionÂ VII.

II Data

We use the single-frequency full-mission maps from the Planck NPIPEÂ data release (PR4)Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2020a) in our analysis. These maps are provided in Î¼â¢Kğœ‡K\mathrm{\mu K}italic_Î¼ roman_K (CMB thermodynamic temperature units) at all frequencies, so we do not need to convert between Jy/srJysr\mathrm{Jy/sr}roman_Jy / roman_sr and Î¼â¢Kğœ‡K\mathrm{\mu K}italic_Î¼ roman_K (as might have been necessary for previous releases of the Planck single-frequency maps, some of which provided the highest-frequency maps in Jy/srJysr\mathrm{Jy/sr}roman_Jy / roman_sr). Note that the kinematic solar dipole, which is sourced by the Doppler boosting of the CMB monopole due to our proper motion with respect to the CMB rest frame (in particular our motion through the Galaxy), is not subtracted from these maps. As this is much brighter than the intrinsic CMB fluctuations (with an amplitude of â‰ˆ3367â¢Î¼â¢Kabsent3367ğœ‡K\approx 3367\,\mathrm{\mu K}â‰ˆ 3367 italic_Î¼ roman_KÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2020a), cf.Â the characteristic CMB fluctuation amplitude of âˆ¼40â¢Î¼â¢Ksimilar-toabsent40ğœ‡K\sim 40\,\mathrm{\mu K}âˆ¼ 40 italic_Î¼ roman_K), we subtract it from the maps before using them. To ensure we subtract the same dipole from each map, we use the solar dipole estimation from the Commander component-separation analysis of the NPIPEÂ maps111This is available on NERSC at $CFS/cmb/data/planck2020/all_data/commander_dipole_templates/planck/dipole_CMB_n4096_K.fits. We also subtract the mean of each map before further analysis.

We use the 30, 44, 70, 100, 143, 217, 353, 545, and 857 GHz single-frequency maps. The observed sky signal in these maps is convolved with the Planck instrument beam at the corresponding frequency. We approximate these beams as being Gaussian, with full width at half maximum values (FWHMs) given in TableÂ 1Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2020b). To characterize fully the frequency response of each map, we use the passbands given in Refs.Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2014a, b).

We also use the half-ring split maps from the NPIPE release. These maps are subset maps of the full-mission maps described above, each with the same passbands, beams, etc.Â as the full-mission maps described above, but with independent noise realizations; as such, each half-ring map is noisier than the full-mission map, but they are useful for power spectrum analysis as their cross-power spectrum does not contain bias due to correlations in the instrumental noise. With these maps, we build two independent split maps of the Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y signal.

We use a needlet ILC algorithm to construct a full-sky tSZ map from these frequency maps, with various choices for contaminant deprojection. We discuss the specific details of our needlet ILC pipeline in detail in SectionÂ IV.

III The needlet ILC algorithm

In this section, we discuss the ILC and NILC in general, beginning in PartÂ III.1 with a general definition of ILC, and describing the NILC in PartÂ III.2. We discuss the constrained ILC, which can be used to deproject specific foreground components with known frequency dependence, in PartÂ III.3. Finally in SectionÂ III.4, we discuss the ILC bias. Note that in this section, we remain very general, specializing to the specific details of our NILC pipeline in SectionÂ IV.

Throughout, we use lower-case Latin indices i,j,k,l,m,n,â€¦ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘›â€¦i,j,k,l,m,n,...italic_i , italic_j , italic_k , italic_l , italic_m , italic_n , â€¦ to label components of vectors or matrices in frequency space; subscript â„“,mâ„“ğ‘š\ell,mroman_â„“ , italic_m indices refer to discrete harmonic-space multipole coefficients (while the symbol mğ‘šmitalic_m may seem overloaded, it will always be clear from context to what we refer). Greek indices Î±,Î²,â€¦ğ›¼ğ›½â€¦\alpha,\beta,...italic_Î± , italic_Î² , â€¦ refer to components in the space of sky components that we preserve or deproject.

In the ILC approach, the frequency-frequency covariance matrix is estimated directly from the data, and so the only â€œexternalâ€ knowledge that is needed is the knowledge of the signalâ€™s frequency dependence aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (hence the nomenclature â€œinternalâ€). The covariance can be measured and the weights applied in various bases: for example, in real space, by measuring ğ’iâ¢jsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathcal{C}_{ij}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the entire maps (or subregions of the maps) and calculating one weight for each frequency map; or in harmonic space, by calculating an â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“-dependent covariance matrix ğ’â„“iâ¢jsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘—â„“\mathcal{C}^{ij}_{\ell}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and applying â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“-dependent weights to the harmonic coefficients of the frequency maps in separate multipole bins. The former is ideal if there is no scale dependence to the noise properties, e.g., if the noise and the signal all have power spectra with similar â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“-dependence. If the foregrounds have different â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“-dependence to the signal, or if different foregrounds are relevant at different scales in the different frequency channels, or if the instrumental noise becomes dominant at different values of â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“, then a harmonic ILC is more appropriate. We describe briefly each of these domains below.

III.3 Deprojection of foregrounds: constrained ILC

The weights in Eq.Â (5) are chosen to minimize the variance in the recovered map. However, sometimes certain foregrounds can significantly bias a signal of interest and a slight increase in variance is an acceptable price to pay for a significant reduction of this bias. This can be particularly true for cross-correlation measurements using ILC Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y maps, as some foregrounds are more highly correlated with the field with which we are cross-correlating than the signal we are trying to isolate. For example, the CIB is a foreground for the tSZ effect, and is more highly correlated with CMB lensing than the tSZ signal isÂ Remazeilles etÂ al. (2011b). In such cases, one may choose to build a â€œconstrainedâ€ ILC map, as described in the following.

If the SED of a foreground signal is known, we can â€œdeprojectâ€ it from our final map. In particular, let us now say that the signal in the sky is

III.4 The ILC bias

The ILC bias is a well-known issue in the ILC algorithmÂ Delabrouille etÂ al. (2009), which is caused by the fact that the covariance matrix is estimated directly from the maps, using only a finite number of modes. Chance fluctuations lead to incorrect estimates of the covariance and can lead to correlations between the weights and the signal of interest. This can be minimized by measuring the covariance over a large enough domain with enough modes that the covariance matrix estimation is immune to chance fluctuations.

We can define the ILC bias as follows. Recall the signal estimate is

IV Estimating the tSZ signal

The tSZ spectral distortion is given by

Here hâ„hitalic_h is Planckâ€™s constant, kBsubscriptğ‘˜ğµk_{B}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Boltzmannâ€™s constant, TCMB=2.726subscriptğ‘‡CMB2.726T_{\mathrm{CMB}}=2.726italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CMB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2.726 K is the mean temperature of the CMBÂ Fixsen etÂ al. (1996); Mather etÂ al. (1999); Fixsen (2009), and yâ¢(n^)ğ‘¦^ğ‘›y(\hat{n})italic_y ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) is the dimensionless (and frequency-independent) Compton yğ‘¦yitalic_y-parameter that quantifies the integral of the electron pressure along the line of sight (LOS). An ILC map that preserves the SED given by Eq.Â (37) is a map of the Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y anisotropies in our Universe.

We construct a set of Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y maps from the single-frequency maps of the Planck NPIPEÂ data release (PR4)Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2020a). In our â€œstandard frequency coverageâ€ (default) case, we use the maps at frequencies {30,44,70,100,143,217,353,545}304470100143217353545\{30,44,70,100,143,217,353,545\}{ 30 , 44 , 70 , 100 , 143 , 217 , 353 , 545 } GHz, i.e., we use all of the maps from the Low Frequency Instrument (LFI) and all of the maps from the High Frequency Instrument (HFI) except for that at 857 GHz. We also make an extended-frequency-coverage version which includes 857 GHz, and additionally a version which excludes both 545 and 857 GHz.

The NILC method has been previously applied to Planck data to construct yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps, e.g., in the official Planck analysis of the PR1 (2013)Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2014c) and PR2 (2015) data releasesÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a), along with other component separation algorithms, in particular the modified internal linear combination (MILCA)Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a); Tanimura etÂ al. (2022). Ref.Â Hill and Spergel (2014) (hereafter HS14) used a harmonic ILC (HILC) to construct a Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y map with which to measure the tSZ-CMB lensing cross-correlation, Câ„“yâ¢Îºsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶â„“ğ‘¦ğœ…C_{\ell}^{y\kappa}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y italic_Îº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Notably, Ref.Â Tanimura etÂ al. (2022) applied MILCA to the NPIPEÂ single-frequency maps to build a lower-noise yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map than the 2015 Planck map, and similarly Ref.Â Chandran etÂ al. (2023) has recently applied NILC to the NPIPEÂ maps.

In this section we describe our analysis settings for the NILC algorithm. In SectionÂ IV.1 we present the harmonic- and real-space filters we use for our NILC. We present the pre-processing steps that we apply before performing the NILC analysis in SectionÂ IV.2. We discuss our foreground deprojection methods subsequently in SectionÂ V.

Before performing the needlet decomposition of the single-frequency maps, we convolve them to a common beam. However, note that, while we perform the NILC with many input frequency maps, the lowest-frequency maps have much larger beam FWHMs than the highest-frequency maps, and the signal is exponentially sub-dominant to the instrumental noise on small-to-intermediate scales (after beam deconvolution). Thus, in practice, we drop particular frequency maps from the NILC on the needlet scales where we expect no information from these maps. In particular, we define a â€œbeam threshold criterionâ€ bthreshsubscriptğ‘threshb_{\rm thresh}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which we take to be bthresh=10âˆ’3subscriptğ‘threshsuperscript103b_{\rm thresh}=10^{-3}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If, for a given needlet scale, the beam of a given frequency channel reaches this threshold at a lower â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ than the needlet filter does for that scale, we drop that frequency channel from the NILC. Mathematically: we find the multipole â„“hsubscriptâ„“â„\ell_{h}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where hâ„“hI=bthreshsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ¼subscriptâ„“â„subscriptğ‘threshh^{I}_{\ell_{h}}=b_{\rm thresh}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (on the decreasing side of the needlet filter) and the multipole â„“bsubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{b}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where bâ„“bi=bthreshsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptâ„“ğ‘subscriptğ‘threshb^{i}_{\ell_{b}}=b_{\rm thresh}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We then require that â„“h<â„“bsubscriptâ„“â„subscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{h}<\ell_{b}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in order for a frequency map to be included in the NILC at this needlet scale. If this criterion is not satisfied for the beam of a given frequency channel, then that channel is dropped from the NILC at this needlet scale. Note that this procedure assumes monotonicity of the beam function, and also assumes that the filter function has a peak (and thus a decreasing region). The latter assumption does not hold for the smallest-scale needlet filter (see FigureÂ 1), so for this scale we simply use the same maps as used at the penultimate needlet scale.

The resulting real-space FWHM values that we use to construct our NILC maps are listed in TableÂ 3; note that they in principle depend on the number of foregrounds deprojected Ndeprojsubscriptğ‘deprojN_{\mathrm{deproj}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_deproj end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with smaller real-space FWHMs allowed when deprojecting more components (at fixed btolsuperscriptğ‘tolb^{\rm tol}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_tol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Note that, in practice, Nfreqsubscriptğ‘freqN_{\mathrm{freq}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_freq end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on the needlet scale, as we drop the lower-resolution maps from the higher-resolution needlet scales according to TableÂ 2.

Once we have defined the domains ğ’Ÿn^real,Isuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿ^ğ‘›realğ¼\mathcal{D}_{\hat{n}}^{\mathrm{real},I}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real , italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we calculate the mean and the frequency-frequency covariance of the needlet coefficients TiIâ¢(n^)superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ¼^ğ‘›T_{i}^{I}(\hat{n})italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) on them by smoothing each quantity with a Gaussian beam of the appropriate FWHM. In particular, the mean is simply given by the smoothed needlet coefficient maps, while the covariance is calculated by subtracting these means from the full needlet coefficient maps and multiplying them together, then smoothing the result.

IV.2 Pre-processing details

Before applying the NILC algorithm to the data, we apply a mask to each single-frequency map to remove very bright Galactic emission and point sources. This prevents the dominant emission from these regions (which, even if retained, would be masked in the final analysis) from significantly affecting the ILC weights calculated slightly away from (but in the vicinity of) these regions, and thus allows for better component separation away from these regions.

We inpaint the regions of each map covered by these masks using a diffusive inpainting scheme, which iteratively replaces masked pixels with â‰¥4absent4\geq 4â‰¥ 4 unmasked neighbors by the mean of the surrounding unmasked pixels. The Galactic mask we use is the same as that used in the pre-processing of the Planck 2015 NILC tSZ mapÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a), which we download from the Planck Legacy Archive (PLA)444This is available at http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=COM_CompMap_Compton-SZMap-nilc-ymaps_2048_R2.00.fits (field =3absent3=3= 3).. The point source mask we use is the point source catalogue mask from Planck, which we also download from the PLA, using the low-frequency catalogue for the LFI maps and the high-frequency catalogue for the HFI maps555These are available at http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=HFI_Mask_PointSrc_2048_R2.00.fits (HFI) and http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=LFI_Mask_PointSrc_2048_R2.00.fits (LFI).. These preprocessing masks are shown in FigureÂ 2. The Galactic mask covers 2.85% of the sky; the HFI point source mask covers 1.37% of the sky; and the LFI point source mask covers 5.41% of the sky. The combination of the Galactic mask and the HFI point source mask covers 3.93% of the sky and the combination of the Galactic mask and the LFI point source mask covers 7.94% of the sky; the combination of all three covers 8.50% of the sky, which at the end defines the total masked sky area of our final NILC maps.

As the NPIPEÂ single-frequency maps retain the dominant contribution from the kinematic dipole, before inpainting we remove the kinematic dipole as measured by the Commander component separation algorithmÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2020a), and then subtract the remaining monopoles of the maps. Finally, following Ref.Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a), we deconvolve the beams of each map (the beams of the Planck maps are listed in Ref.Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2020b); we repeat them in TableÂ 1) and reconvolve all maps to a common beam of 10â€²superscript10â€²10^{\prime}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that, as the covariances are calculated in real space, the beam at which the NILC is performed can significantly affect the final result, as the needlet filters are so broad in scale that the large variance of the small-scale modes can contribute significantly if they are not sufficiently beam-convolved. Thus the weights can spuriously adapt to mitigate the variance sourced by the smallest-scale modes in these frequency channels. Such an impact could be mitigated by choosing needlet scales with less broad coverage in â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“-space. In this work, however, we choose to follow the official Planck analysis and perform the NILC on maps at 10â€²superscript10â€²10^{\prime}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT resolution.

V Deprojection of various components

In SectionÂ III.3, we discussed constrained ILC and foreground deprojection. In this section we present our specific choices for foreground deprojection, in particular for removing the CMB and the CIB.

V.1 Deprojection of the CIB

For many cross-correlation analyses of the tSZ signal with large-scale structure (LSS) tracers, it is necessary to deproject the CIB, which is also correlated with LSS and which can bias a âŸ¨yÃ—Lâ¢Sâ¢SâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘¦ğ¿ğ‘†ğ‘†\langle y\times LSS\rangleâŸ¨ italic_y Ã— italic_L italic_S italic_S âŸ© measurement if unmitigated. However, unlike the tSZ and CMB signals, which display no frequency decorrelation and which have SEDs that are well understood from first principles and can thus be calculated theoretically, the CIB is not described perfectly by one SED. It is sourced by the line-of-sight integrated thermal emission of different objects; in particular, different frequency channels are sensitive to slightly different objects, as source emission at different redshifts will be redshifted into different frequency bands. This leads to frequency decorrelation between the CIB channels. However, as the correlation coefficients are â‰³90greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsent90\gtrsim 90â‰³ 90% at the frequencies of interestÂ Viero etÂ al. (2013); Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2014d); Mak etÂ al. (2017); Lenz etÂ al. (2019), it is still possible to clean the CIB using multi-frequency measurements. Its SED does not need to be known for the unconstrained ILC; however, if we wish to explicitly deproject it, we must model its SED.

The CIB monopole is sourced at zâ‰ˆ2ğ‘§2z\approx 2italic_z â‰ˆ 2, which would predict a redshifted temperature of â‰ˆ12.1â¢Kabsent12.1K\approx 12.1\,\,\mathrm{K}â‰ˆ 12.1 roman_K, not far from our best-fit effective temperatures.

V.2 Deprojection of the first moments of the CIB

There is significant uncertainty on the parameters (Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², TCIBeffsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‡CIBeffT_{\mathrm{CIB}}^{\mathrm{eff}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) of the CIB SED; additionally, it is not a perfect approximation to the CIB emission to describe it as an exact modified blackbody described by a single set of these parameters. For cross-correlations of the tSZ effect with tracers that are more highly correlated with the CIB than with the tSZ field itself (e.g., the CMB lensing potential), imperfect removal of the CIB due to a deprojection with the â€œincorrectâ€ SED can result in a CIB residual that is still a significant bias to the measurement. This systematic must therefore be considered and mitigated when measuring such a cross-correlation, such as in our companion paperÂ McCarthy and Hill (2024) where we measure the tSZ â€“ CMB lensing cross-correlation.

In Ref.Â Chluba etÂ al. (2017), a moment-based approach for the description and removal of mm-wave foregrounds was introduced. In particular, their method was designed to mitigate effects due to SED uncertainty or variation of SED parameters due to either spatial averaging within an instrumentâ€™s beam or along the line-of-sight; the latter is particularly important for foregrounds such as the CIB, which is not emitted at only one redshift but in fact has a wide redshift kernel and is a superposition of imperfect modified blackbodies at various redshifts.

In this approach, the underlying (fundamental) SED is parametrized by some free parameters ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p, such as a modified blackbody parametrized by (Î²,T)ğ›½ğ‘‡(\beta,T)( italic_Î² , italic_T ). One then considers variations of these parameters within the instrument beam (and/or sky map pixel) or along the line-of-sight, both of which generically lead to deviations of the â€œmeasuredâ€ SED away from the fundamental SED form. The observed SED can be represented as a Taylor expansion (in the parameters ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p) around a point in parameter space ğ©Â¯Â¯ğ©\bar{\mathbf{p}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG, and more accurately modeled using this Taylor expansion. The zeroth-order moment of the observed SED is the average SED, which can be written as the fundamental SED evaluated at ğ©Â¯Â¯ğ©\bar{\mathbf{p}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG. If there were no variations in the SED parameters, then no further modeling would be needed. However, in general such variations lead to higher-order terms (moments) in the Taylor expansion. Then, the more appropriate SED to use for deprojection in a constrained ILC would be not only the SED evaluated at ğ©Â¯Â¯ğ©\bar{\mathbf{p}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG, but the entire Taylor expansion. In particular, the SED and its first (and higher-order) derivatives with respect to ğ©ğ©{\mathbf{p}}bold_p (evaluated at ğ©Â¯Â¯ğ©\bar{\mathbf{p}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG) can be considered as independent components to be deprojected in a constrained ILC. Of course, given a finite number of frequency channels, we do not have the freedom to deproject an infinite number of components, but with the multi-frequency coverage of Planck it is possible to deproject several components.

We will use this approach to deproject the CIB in a robust manner from our yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map. In particular, we deproject the first moment of the CIB with respect to Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², which in practice amounts to deprojecting an additional component with an SED given by âˆ‚IÎ½CIBâˆ‚Î²superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœˆCIBğ›½\frac{\partial I_{\nu}^{\mathrm{CIB}}}{\partial\beta}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_Î² end_ARG, and also the first moment of the CIB with respect to TCIBeffsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‡effCIBT^{\mathrm{eff}}_{\mathrm{CIB}}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which similarly amounts to deprojecting an additional component with an SED given by âˆ‚IÎ½CIBâˆ‚TCIBeffsuperscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœˆCIBsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‡effCIB\frac{\partial I_{\nu}^{\mathrm{CIB}}}{\partial T^{\mathrm{eff}}_{\mathrm{CIB}}}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

V.3 Deprojection of the CMB

The CMB, whose SED is known (nearly) perfectly, can be deprojected in a constrained ILC tSZ map with no uncertainty or need to consider additional moments. This can be useful for large-scale cross-correlations of the tSZ signal with LSS, as the large-scale CMB contains contributions sourced by LSS arising from the integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) effectÂ Sachs and Wolfe (1967). This ISW-LSS correlation (e.g.,Â Lewis etÂ al. (2011); Creque-Sarbinowski etÂ al. (2016); Hill (2018)) can bias such measurements, including the tSZ â€“ CMB lensing cross-correlation. However, we do not have enough frequency channels to deproject more than three components at small scales (unless 857 GHz information is included); see TableÂ 2. Thus we elect to only deproject the CMB from the first five needlet scales in some cases, denoted â€œCMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTâ€. As the ISW is a large-scale effect, this should mitigate essentially all of the LSS bias due to the ISW contribution.

The (normalized) SEDs of various components of interest are plotted in FigureÂ 5.

VI Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y map validation and comparison to Planck map

In this section we present and validate our Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y maps, estimate their power spectra, and compare them to the official Planck 2015 tSZ NILC map. We explicitly compute the auto-power spectra and 1-D histograms of our maps and compare them to those of the official Planck analysis (on the same region of sky) in SectionÂ VI.2. In SectionÂ VI.3 we quantify the variance increase resulting from our various deprojections, by comparing the power spectra of our undeprojected and deprojected maps; we also illustrate the effects of varying the frequency coverage in the NILC. Finally, in SectionÂ VI.4, we compare the level of CIB contamination in our maps to that of the official Planck release, and also present the results of deprojecting the CIB. We perform all power spectrum calculations throughout with NaMasterÂ Alonso etÂ al. (2019).

Note that the 2015 Planck map was made with the CMB deprojected, and so all direct comparisons between our map and the Planck map are done with our CMB-deprojected map.

VI.1 Map images

We show our resulting tSZ maps in FigureÂ 6, including various deprojection choices and also showing the official Planck 2015 NILC tSZ mapÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a) for comparison. For the cases when just the CIB or the CIB+CMB are deprojected, there is no significant change to the maps by eye. However, when we deproject Î´â¢Î²ğ›¿ğ›½\delta\betaitalic_Î´ italic_Î², the map becomes visibly noisier; we see that when we deproject both Î´â¢Î²ğ›¿ğ›½\delta\betaitalic_Î´ italic_Î² and the CMB the map is even noisier, indicating that there is significant CMB contamination in the CIB+Î´â¢Î²ğ›¿ğ›½\delta\betaitalic_Î´ italic_Î²-deprojected map. Finally, the maps with both moments of the CIB deprojected have significantly higher variance, and it becomes difficult to pick out structures such as the Coma cluster, which appears as a bright point in the northern hemisphere (right hand side of the maps) by eye. In the legend of FigureÂ 6, and later, CMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT-deprojection refers to the deprojection of the CMB on only the first five needlet scales.

VI.2 Comparison with Planck map: histograms and power spectra

To compare directly with the Planck yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map, we consider histograms of the Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y values in the maps and also compute their auto-power spectra (for our various deprojection choices) on the area of sky defined by the Planck yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map analysis mask, which is provided with the Planck yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map999It can be found at http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=COM_CompMap_Compton-SZMap-masks_2048_R2.01.fits, with field=1.. This mask, which is apodized, covers 50% of the sky. We multiply this mask by the point source mask, defined by the union of the Planck HFI and LFI point source masks as described in Ref.Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016a). When we estimate the power spectra, we apodize the point source mask with an apodization scale of 30â€²superscript30â€²30^{\prime}30 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT before multiplying it with the Planck analysis mask (for the histograms, we use an unapodized point source mask). The resulting apodized mask allows for analysis with an effective fsky=0.45subscriptğ‘“sky0.45f_{\mathrm{sky}}=0.45italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_sky end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.45101010Note that, at some level, the point source mask is correlated with the tSZ field itself; however, any biases resulting from this correlation (e.g.,Â Fabbian etÂ al. (2021); Lembo etÂ al. (2022); Surrao etÂ al. (2023)) are expected to be negligible at Planck sensitivity..

VI.2.1 Histograms

We show the histograms of the Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y pixel values in FigureÂ 7, for our maps with no deprojection (standard ILC, blue), fiducial CIB modified blackbody SED deprojected (orange), and additionally with the first moment of the CIB SED with respect to Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² deprojected (green) and with both moments deprojected (red); we include all versions both with and without the CMB deprojected, with the CMB-deprojected versions shown in solid lines compared to the dashed lines for the cases when we do not deproject the CMB (we only deproject the CMB on the first five needlet scales in the case where we deproject both moments of the CIB due to the insufficient frequency coverage on small scales to deproject more components). We also show the histogram for the official Planck 2015 tSZ map in black. The Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y signal is highly non-Gaussian and the strong positive tail is indicative of the presence of tSZ signal due to groups and clusters, which we see in all of the maps except for the case when we deproject both moments of the CIB; in this case, the large foreground contribution is larger than this signal. We note that there is more noise in the CIB-deprojected maps, and significantly more noise in the moments-deprojected maps, as indicated by the broadening of the histograms. This is an inevitable consequence of deprojecting more components in a constrained ILC.

We note that the histograms of our no-deprojection (standard ILC) and CMB-deprojected yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps agree very well with that of the Planck map.

VI.2.2 Auto-power spectra

We measure the power spectra of our yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps to further characterize their properties. We also construct NILC yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps with, and measure the cross-power spectra of, two independent split maps which have independent noise (and therefore no noise bias in the power spectrum). We show the results in FigureÂ 8. We also calculate the auto-power spectrum of the Planck yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map on the same sky area. In all cases, we calculate the power spectra using NaMaster to decouple the mask mode-coupling matrix.

The auto-power spectrum of our standard ILC yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map is slightly lower (â‰ˆ10âˆ’20%absent10percent20\approx 10-20\%â‰ˆ 10 - 20 %) on small scales than that of the Planck 2015 yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map, presumably due to the lower instrumental noise in the PR4 NPIPEÂ data compared to PR3. VI.3 Effect of various deprojections and varying frequency coverage

In FigureÂ 9, we show how various contaminant deprojection choices used in our NILC analyses affect the final auto-power spectrum of the yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map. In all cases, when we deproject the CIB and its first moments, we use the best-fit CIB SED parameters from SectionÂ V.1, Î²=1.77ğ›½1.77\beta=1.77italic_Î² = 1.77 and TCIBeff=10.14â¢Ksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‡CIBeff10.14KT_{\mathrm{CIB}}^{\mathrm{eff}}=10.14\,\mathrm{K}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 10.14 roman_K. We see that deprojecting the CIB incurs a small increase in noise power, but the CMB deprojection leaves the power essentially unaffected, as long as either no other components or the CIB alone is deprojected. This is because the CMB is already the dominant astrophysical contaminant in the standard ILC, so the weights are quite similar regardless of whether it is deprojected. However, deprojecting the moments of the CIB incurs much more serious noise penalties, particularly if multiple moments are deprojected. Note that, for the case when we deproject both moments of the CIB, there are not enough frequency channels to also deproject the CMB on small scales, and so we only deproject the CMB in the first five needlet scales; we refer to this in the legends of FiguresÂ 9,Â 10, and Â 11 as â€œCMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTâ€.

Our fiducial yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map includes information from all Planck frequency channels except for 857 GHz. For comparison, we also construct maps including 857 GHz in the NILC, as well as dropping 545 GHz. We note that the official Planck analysis (as well as the analysis of Ref.Â Chandran etÂ al. (2023)) uses 857 GHz only at â„“<300â„“300\ell<300roman_â„“ < 300, due to its uncertain calibration. In principle, one could co-add the â„“<300â„“300\ell<300roman_â„“ < 300 modes of our with-857 GHz map with the â„“>300â„“300\ell>300roman_â„“ > 300 modes of our no-857 GHz map to obtain such a map.

The effects of including 857 GHz and dropping 545 GHz are shown in FiguresÂ 10 andÂ 11, respectively. As expected, as there is more (less) data, including more (fewer) frequency channels results in lower (higher) power in the final yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map. However, we note that when more high-frequency channels are included, more information about the CIB SED is required in order to deproject it robustly, and it can be more difficult to robustly remove all CIB contamination; we discuss this issue in detail in our companion paperÂ McCarthy and Hill (2024).

VI.4 CIB contamination

We attempt to quantify the amount of residual CIB in our Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y maps by directly cross-correlating them with maps of the CIB. CIB maps are difficult to construct due to the difficulty of separating CIB emission from Galactic dust emission, which is dominant on large scales and has a very similar frequency dependence to the CIB. We use the CIB maps of Ref.Â Lenz etÂ al. (2019), which were constructed by using HI dataÂ HI4PI Collaboration etÂ al. (2016) as a tracer of the Galactic dust in order to clean the dust emission from the highest-frequency (353, 545, 857 GHz) Planck channels. The resulting maps of the CIB emission at these frequencies are very clean of Galactic contamination.

For this investigation, we use only the 857 GHz CIB map, as the maps were constructed with the PR3 Planck data and thus do not have maps built from the same independent noise realizations as the NPIPEÂ maps. Thus, we do not have two independent splits that are required to make a measurement without instrumental noise bias. However, as we do not use 857 GHz in our default NILC yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map construction, we can make a measurement with the 857 GHz map that is immune to noise bias. It would be interesting in the future to repeat or extend the work of Ref.Â Lenz etÂ al. (2019) to the NPIPEÂ data in order to measure cross-correlations with the lower frequencies that do not contain noise bias. An additional advantage of using the 857 GHz map for the tSZ-CIB cross-correlation is that this is the channel in which the intrinsic yğ‘¦yitalic_y signal is most suppressed compared to the CIB. For lower frequencies (particularly 353 GHz and below), we would have to consider the âŸ¨yCIBâˆ’mapâ¢yNILCâˆ’mapâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘¦CIBmapsuperscriptğ‘¦NILCmap\left<y^{\rm CIB-map}y^{\mathrm{NILC-map}}\right>âŸ¨ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB - roman_map end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_NILC - roman_map end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© contribution to the signal.

We show in FigureÂ 12 the cross-power spectra measured with the 857 GHz CIB map and our standard-frequency-coverage NILC yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps for several deprojection choices. We also include the measurement using the official PlanckÂ Â map. We perform these measurements with the cleanest map provided by Ref.Â Lenz etÂ al. (2019), which covers 8.71% of the sky. We multiply the apodized mask provided by Ref.Â Lenz etÂ al. (2019) with the mask used previously throughout this work, i.e., the official PlanckÂ Â NILC mask combined with the point source masks. The final sky covarage is 8.47% in our tSZ-CIB cross-correlation measurement.

In FigureÂ 12, it is clear that the CIB contamination in our yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps is lower than that of the official PlanckÂ Â yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map. This is consistent with the results of Ref.Â Chandran etÂ al. (2023). It is encouraging that the lower instrumental noise in the NPIPEÂ maps has allowed for improved subtraction of the foregrounds in this case.

In FigureÂ 12, we also include a theoretical prediction for the intrinsic cross-power spectrum between the tSZ and the CIB emission at 857 GHz Câ„“yâ¢857superscriptsubscriptğ¶â„“ğ‘¦857C_{\ell}^{y{\rm 857}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y 857 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We note that there is significant model uncertainty in this prediction. The methodology that we use follows the halo model formalism used to calculate the auto-power spectrum. While we defer to our companion paperÂ McCarthy and Hill (2024) an in-depth presentation of the halo model details, we note that the model in FigureÂ 12 (which was calculated with class_sz) uses the pressure profiles of Ref.Â Battaglia etÂ al. (2010); Battaglia etÂ al. (2012b) to predict the tSZ signal along with the halo model of Ref.Â Shang etÂ al. (2012) with the parameter values of Ref.Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2014d) to predict the CIB signal (see Ref.Â McCarthy and Madhavacheril (2021) for a detailed description of this incarnation of the CIB halo model). As the focus of this paper is not the CIB-tSZ cross-correlation, we do not consider a wider range of models (although note that a prediction for this signal was made in Ref.Â Maniyar etÂ al. (2021), and it would be interesting to use this data to constrain this model). We note that, if it is truly CIB-free, the fully moment-deprojected (CIB+Î´â¢Î²ğ›¿ğ›½\delta\betaitalic_Î´ italic_Î²+Î´â¢TeffCIBğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡effCIB\delta T_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\mathrm{CIB}}italic_Î´ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT+CMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT) data points in FigureÂ 12 can be interpreted directly as a measurement of the intrinsic cross-correlation of Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y and the CIB. Such a measurement was previously made with PlanckÂ Â data in Ref.Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016b). We defer to future work a comparison between our data and the measurements in this reference. Indeed, our work in Ref.Â McCarthy and Hill (2024) relies on the assumption that the fully moment-deprojected yğ‘¦yitalic_y-map is indeed negligibly contaminated by CIB. In FigureÂ 12, we also include the data points as measured by Ref.Â Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2014b). As such, we hope that these maps will make possible a fruitful joint CIB-tSZ analysis.

VII Discussion

In this work, we have presented pyilc, a fully public Python package to perform NILC on full-sky HEALPix maps. We hope that pyilc will be useful both for analyses of real data, to isolate maps of the CMB and tSZ signals and any other component whose spectral signature is known, as well as for analyses of simulations, in particular in cases where one wants to test a signal-extraction pipeline on realistic data and to understand biases due to foregrounds. We have validated that our implementation in pyilc produces maps that closely match the official PlanckÂ tSZ maps (when making the same analysis choices), which were produced with a non-public pipeline. Our code is fully available and easily extensible to consider other sky components and other deprojection options.

We have used pyilc to perform NILC on the Planck NPIPEÂ data to isolate the (almost) full-sky Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y signal in our Universe. We note that yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps have previously been made with this dataÂ Tanimura etÂ al. (2022); Chandran etÂ al. (2023), as well as in the official PlanckÂ analysisÂ Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2014c, 2016a). We have made several improvements to the analysis, including a slightly different input-map-processing step where we mask the point sources such that they do not contribute to the calculation of the NILC weights; as point sources are always masked in any final analysis mask, this does not affect any science obtained from the maps, but improves their noise properties and usable sky fractions. Additionally, we provide yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps where we have explicitly removed the CIB by deprojecting both a modified blackbody component and its first moments. Our CMB-deprojected tSZ map has â‰ˆ10absent10\approx 10â‰ˆ 10% lower noise than that in the official PlanckÂ Â 2015 tSZ map.

We quantify the amount of CIB contamination in our maps by directly cross-correlating them with maps of the CIB. We find that our maps have less CIB contamination than the 2015 PlanckÂ Â NILC map. We have also presented CIB-moment-deprojected yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps, which we hope can be used to measure âŸ¨yâˆ’Lâ¢Sâ¢SâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘¦ğ¿ğ‘†ğ‘†\left<y-LSS\right>âŸ¨ italic_y - italic_L italic_S italic_S âŸ© cross-correlations without CIB bias.

We use these yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps in our companion paperÂ McCarthy and Hill (2024) to detect the cross-correlation of the reconstructed CMB lensing signal and the tSZ signal, for only the second timeÂ Hill and Spergel (2014), and with significantly more robustness against CIB contaminationÂ Hurier (2015). We hope that our techniques for removing the CIB from such a measurement will be useful for a wide range of future tSZ cross-correlation analyses, including the tSZ-CIB cross-correlationÂ Maniyar etÂ al. (2021); Planck Collaboration etÂ al. (2016b).

We note that PlanckÂ yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps, while currently state-of-the-art, will shortly be surpassed in signal-to-noise ratio by upcoming data from ACTÂ Henderson etÂ al. (2016), SPT-3GÂ Benson etÂ al. (2014), and soon the Simons ObservatoryÂ Ade etÂ al. (2019). However, the PlanckÂ data will remain dominant in the Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y reconstruction for the foreseeable future at â„“â‰²1000less-than-or-similar-toâ„“1000\ell\lesssim 1000roman_â„“ â‰² 1000, as atmospheric noise becomes too large at low multipoles for ground-based experiments to surpass PlanckÂ (in temperature) over this range â€” see, e.g., FigureÂ 36 of Ref.Â Ade etÂ al. (2019). A hybrid combination of the ground-based and space-based data will thus become the standard approach in the near future (as already demonstrated in Refs.Â Madhavacheril etÂ al. (2020); Aghanim etÂ al. (2019)).

VIII Summary of Public Products

We make various configurations of our Compton-yğ‘¦yitalic_y maps publicly available at https://users.flatironinstitute.org/~fmccarthy/ymaps_PR4_McCH23/. We also release our full NILC pipeline at https://github.com/jcolinhill/pyilc/, which takes as input a set of single-frequency maps and executes the NILC algorithms described in this paper; we include as explanatory files several input files we used to construct our NILC yğ‘¦yitalic_y-maps from the Planck data products. We note that the input is not the raw single-frequency NPIPEÂ maps but instead the monopole- and dipole-subtracted, inpainted NPIPEÂ maps described earlier in this work. We also release our inpainting code in the same GitHub repository as pyilc, along with our inpainting mask and several analysis masks, which are also at https://sdsc-users.flatironinstitute.org/~fmccarthy/ymaps_PR4_McCH23/.
